title: ASX tumbles as trade tensions grow, Flight Centre skids
text:
"At the moment, where these markets are, there is little room for any negative news," said Vertium Asset Management's chief investment officer Jason Teh. "There is little margin for safety."

A poor session on Wall Street set the Australian market up for a downbeat trading day, with the Dow shedding 1.2 per cent, the S &P 500 falling 1.6 per cent and the Nasdaq losing 1.7 per cent.

US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said that the Fed would be "data dependent" when assessing the outlook. "We will act as appropriate," Mr Powell said, adding "policy is not a preset course."

The US also moved to blacklist a number of Chinese companies and impose visa restrictions on some Chinese officials ahead of fresh trade talks between Washington and Beijing on Thursday.

"Markets are nervous," said Shane Oliver, chief economist at AMP Capital.

The economist said that markets are uncertain about the ongoing trade war and the fallout of trade restrictions to global growth. "On the other hand, there is the prospects for more [monetary] stimulus," he said.

"Rate cuts are helping but there is the risk that the impact declines with every bit of negative data we get," Dr Oliver said.

The International Monetary Fund this week warned that the global economy is experiencing a "synchronised slowdown", and stated that the downturn would worsen if governments failed to resolve trade conflicts and support growth.

Commodity prices are sensitive to global growth expectations and most miners were lower through the Australian trading session.

BHP shares fell 1.4 per cent to $35.13 and Fortescue Metals Group dropped 2.4 per cent to $87.75. Gold extractors managed to advance, however, with Newcrest Mining up 1 per cent at $36.31 and Northern Star up 2.1 per cent to $11.82.

Banks fell, with Australia and New Zealand Banking Group down 1.2 per cent at $27.09, Westpac down 0.9 per cent at $28.43, Commonwealth Bank down 0.5 per cent at $78.18 and National Australia Bank marginally lower, down 0.1 per cent at $28.06.

"Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate cuts are putting pressure on net interest margins," said Mr Teh, speaking about the banking sector. "There is earnings pressure but PE ratios don't reflect that," he said.

AMP dropped to a record low of $1.60, falling 4.2 per cent. Healthcare giant CSL slipped 0.7 per cent to $238.86, Woolworths fell 1 per cent to $36.70 and QBE Insurance declined 1.6 per cent to $12.10.

Qantas shares fell 1.3 per cent at $6.32 after Goldman Sachs took the airline down to neutral from buy and dropped the carrier from its regional conviction list. A strong share price performance since August and uncertainty over the medium-term outlook were behind the downgrade.

Clinuvel Pharmaceuticals was a standout performer in the healthcare sector after its shares shot up 60.2 per cent to $45. The firm told investors that the US Food & Drug Administration has granted approval to supply its Scenesse drug for treatment of adult patients with the rare metabolic disorder erythropoietic protoporphyria.

Cleanaway was another strong performer, rising 6.3 per cent to $2.04 after it made a successful bid to acquire the assets of SKM Recycling Group, which was placed into receivership in August.
description: The ASX fell sharply as trade tensions moved up another notch and a profit warning put a dent in Flight Centre shares, offsetting a sharp rise for Clinuvel.
